description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Forest & Farm Facility (FFF) is a mechanism for financing and capacity building with the purpose of strengthening producer organizations in their work for economic, environmental and social development, as well as promoting their participation in forest and agriculture related policy dialogue and consultation. It will establish initially in 7 countries in Latin America, Asia and Africa, but may expand when additional funding comes in. The program is implemented by four organizations in cooperation, FAO, IIED, IUCN and Agricord. FFF is a development of the FAO's previous initiative for development of local forestry, but is more focused on giving farmers associations and their members better access to markets and decision making fora, as well as a focus on gender and climate adaptation.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 The Forest & Farm Facility (FFF) är en mekanism för finansiering och kapacitetsbyggande med syfte att stärka producentorganisationer i deras arbete för ekonomisk, miljömässig och social utveckling, samt främja deras deltagande i skogs- o lantbruksrelaterad politisk dialog o samråd. Den verkar initialt i 7 länder i Latinamerika, Asien och Afrika, men kan expandera när ytterligare finansiering kommer in. Programmet genomförs av fyra organisationer i samarbete, FAO, IIED ,IUCN och Agricord. FFF är en utveckling av FAOs tidigare initiativ för utveckling av lokalt skogsbruk, men mer inriktad på att främja bondeorganisationers och deras medlemmars tillgång till marknad och beslutsfora, samt klimatanpassning och jämställdhet.

IN SWEDISH Programmets övergripande syfte är att bidra till klimat-resilienta landskap och förbättrad försörjning (med producent-organisationer inom lantbruk/jord-/skogsbruk som betydande förändringsaktörer), med fyra huvudmålsättningar: 1. Mer inkluderande styre och förvaltning samt tvärsektoriella processer leder till anpassade policies och ramverk (SDG 16 & 17), 2. Ökat företagande, tillgång till marknader och finansiering genom rättvisa värdekedjor och tjänster för affärsutveckling inom lantbruks- och producentorganisationer (SDG 1, 5, 8 & 12), 3. Lantbruks- och producentorganisationer bidrar till utsläppsminskning, klimatanpassning och resiliens på landskapsnivå med hållbara försörjningsmöjligheter (SDG 2,3 &15), 4. Förbättrad och jämlik tillgång till sociala och kulturella tjänster (SDG 3&10) Begreppet "lantbruks- och producentorganisationer" används här i första hand med tanke på det småskaliga lantbruket, och definieras enligt projektdokumentet: - Lantbrukare (forest and farm producers) är kvinnor och män, småbrukarfamiljer, urfolk och lokalsamhällen som har en stark relation till skogs- och jordbruk (forests and farms) i skogliga landskap. - Lantbruks- och producentorganisationer (Forest-and-farm producer organisations, FFPO) är formella och informella intresseföreningar av de producenter som beskrivs ovan. Organisationerna är skapade för att underlätta medlemmarnas utbyte av kunskap och erfarenhet, politisk påverkan, säkrande av mark- och naturresursrättigheter, tillgång till marknader, företagande, dvs öka inkomster och välfärd. De varierar i form, storlek, inriktning, t ex sammanslutningar av urfolk, medlemmar i en by, trädjordbrukare, skogsägare, kooperativ, företag och deras paraplyorganisationer. IN ENGLISH The overall objective is to contribute to Climate resilient landscapes and improved livelihoods through four outcomes: 1. More inclusive governance and cross-sectorial processes lead to enabling policies (SDG 16 &17); 2. Increased entrepreneurship, access to markets and finance through equitable value chain and business development services within FFPOs (SDG 1, 5, 8 & 12). 3. Improved delivery of landscape scale mitigation, adaptation and resilience to climate change through direct engagement of FFPOs and integration with inclusive livelihood approaches (SDG 2, 13, &15) 4. Improved and equitable access to social and cultural services (SDG 3 & 10). The focus of the Forest and Farm Facility is on small-scale forest- and farm producers and their organisations. The following definitions are provided by the project document: Forest-and-farm producers are women and men, smallholder families, indigenous peoples and local communities who have strong relationships with forests and farms in forested landscapes. Such producers grow, manage, harvest and process a wide range of natural-resource-based goods and services for subsistence use and for sale in local, national or international markets. Forest-and-farm producer organizations (FFPOs) are formal or informal associations of such producers. They are created with the aim of helping their members share knowledge and experience; engage in policy advocacy; secure tenure and access rights to forest, land and other natural resources; improve forest-and-farm management; expand markets; build enterprises; and increase income and well-being. FFPOs vary widely in size and institutional form and may focus on forests or combinations of forest- and farm-related activities. They may include indigenous peoples and local community organizations; tree-grower and agroforestry associations; forest owner associations; producer cooperatives and companies; and their umbrella groups and federations.

description.narrative: Within the overall impact goal of achieving climate resilient landscapes and improved livelihoods the following results have been accomplished within the four outcome areas: Outcome area 1 – enabling policy and legal frameworks: A total of 13 changes in policy/legal documents, processes or decisions that work in favour of the interest of FFPOs have been achieved on national and international level. Country level examples include Nepal, where active advocacy supported by FFF provided input into the formation and improvement in Forest Act and in Zambia, FFF continues to provide inputs into the countries new Charcoal Regulations (NAT/INST). There are also several challenges in the work under this outcome. FFPO capacity is often low (internal governance, financial and administrative capacity), and there is a general prevalence of low gender equality. The coordination both sectoral and stakeholder wise is also inefficient. Frequent changes in institutions and high turnover of authorities at the ministry level means slow policy processes and at times conflicting sectoral policies. Outcome area 2: Increased entrepreneurship, access to markets and finance. Country level examples include; improved access to finance and markets in Nepal, with 221 community forestry producer groups linked to government enterprise funding. Furthermore, a tree inventory improved fair market prices in Kenya through the launch of a timber tree census in Nyandarua, whereby 3 000 farmer members were supported to undertake tree inventory of on-farm trees as a mean of improving market information for buyers and thereby their capacity to negotiate a fair market price. Initial results of the census show an average of 1.6 million trees per ha representing USD 17 million in potential income. Outcome 3: Improved delivery of landscape-scale mitigation, adaptation and climate resilience; examples include in Bolivia where FFPOs have been able to leverage access to USD 21.7 million in government funding for ecological cocoa agroforestry systems. FFF together with IUCN organized the Tecpan Learning Exchange that hosted 42 participants and explored barriers and urgent policy issues relevant to indigenous peoples. It included opportunities to influence the CBD, UNFCCC, SDGs and other relevant global policies. Important topics related to conserved and protected areas, and how they relate to indigenous rights to land, territories and resources were covered (GLOB/NORM). Outcome 4: :Improved and equitable access to social and cultural services. For example, the Federation of Community Producers Organization of Nepal organized a national 16- day campaign against gender-based violence.
